revision.text:
'''Thermae Basilicae''' was a town in the [[Roman province]] of [[Cappadocia Prima]]. Accordingly, its [[bishopric]], which is included in the [[Catholic Church]]'s list of [[titular see]]s, was a [[Suffragan diocese|suffragan]] of [[Kayseri|Caesarea in Cappadocia]], the capital of the province.<ref>''Annuario Pontificio 2013'' (Libreria Editrice Vaticana, 2013, {{ISBN|978-88-209-9070-1}}), p. 987</ref>
==Description== The town is mentioned as Therma by [[Hierocles (author of Synecdemus)|Hierocles]] (Synecdemus, 699, 2) and is quite probably to be identified with Aquae Sarvenae, which the [[Tabula Peutingeriana]] places on the road between Tavium and Caesarea, and with Sarvena, a city described on an inscription and by Ptolemy (V, 6, 12). This would be today Terzili Hammam, a village about 60 miles north of Caesarea, where there are hot mineral sulphur waters, still frequented. A part of the building containing the baths is of Roman construction; a Christian inscription has been found thereon.<ref name=CE>{{CathEncy|wstitle=Thermae Basilicae}}</ref>
Down to the 13th century, the [[Notitiae episcopatuum]] describe the see as the first suffragan of Caesarea. Perhaps there was a bishop from the time of St. Basil; in any case four others are mentioned: Firminus, present at the [[Council of Chalcedon]], 451; Photinus, at a Council of Constantinople in 459; Musonius, exiled by Justin I, about 518; Theodore, present at the [[Sixth Ecumenical Council]] of Constantinople, 681, and at the [[Council in Trullo]], 692,<ref name=CE/>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Catholic titular sees in Asia]] [[Category:Historical regions]] [[Category:History of Turkey]]

revision.comment: Importing Wikidata [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Welsh geologist" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper.js|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Welsh geologist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Use British English|date=September 2017}} <!-- Commented out: [[File:TROwen.jpg|thumb|T.R. ("Dick") Owen]] --> '''Thomas Richard Owen''' (1918–1990), also known as 'Dick' or 'T.R.' Owen, was a [[Wales|Welsh]] [[geologist]] with an encyclopaedic knowledge of the rocks of Wales, ranging from regional [[stratigraphy]] and [[tectonics]] to [[geomorphology]] and [[marine geology]]. His research was mainly on the [[Carboniferous]] rocks of [[South Wales]].<ref name=ccgc>{{cite web|title=Professor Thomas Richard (Dick) Owen (1918-1990)|url=http://www.ccgc.gov.uk/landscape--wildlife/geological-gems/geologists-who-changed-the-map/professor-thomas-richard-owen.aspx|publisher=ccgc.gov.uk|accessdate=30 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029195130/http://www.ccgc.gov.uk/landscape--wildlife/geological-gems/geologists-who-changed-the-map/professor-thomas-richard-owen.aspx|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=google>{{cite book|title=Geology Explained in South Wales|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Geology_Explained_in_South_Wales.html?id=0C9_PQAACAAJ&redir_esc=y|publisher=google.com.np|accessdate=30 September 2013}}</ref><ref name=amazon>{{cite web|title=Books by Thomas Richard Owen|url=https://www.amazon.com/Thomas-Richard-Owen/e/B0034OZ90A|publisher=amazon.com|accessdate=30 September 2013}}</ref><ref name=swga>{{cite web|title=GEOLOGISTS’ ASSOCIATION, SOUTH WALES GROUP|url=http://www.swga.org.uk/pdf/thomas.pdf|publisher=swga.org.uk|accessdate=30 September 2013}}</ref>
==Career== Born in Aberdare to a mining family, Dick Owen won a scholarship to [[Merthyr Tydfil]] Grammar School and graduated with first class honours in geology from [[Swansea University]] in 1939. He carried out his postgraduate studies there for the next two years, researching the structure of the [[Vale of Neath]], and was associated with teaching at the university for a further 35 years.
His association with [[Swansea]] was interrupted by the [[World War II|Second World War]], during which he served as a [[Meteorology|meteorological]] officer in the [[Royal Air Force|RAF]], rising to the rank of [[Flight lieutenant]]. While he was based in the [[Azores]], one of his most memorable experiences was deciding, on meteorological grounds, whether it was suitable for [[Winston Churchill|Churchill]] and [[Franklin D. Roosevelt|Roosevelt]] to hold their famous meeting in the mid-Atlantic.
His work on the Vale of Neath was published by the [[Geological Society of London|Geological Society]] in 1954 and was swiftly recognised as a classic. He also wrote and edited a series of papers and books that included ''[[Waterfall Country (Wales)|Geology Explained in South Wales]]'' and ''The Upper [[Paleozoic|Palaeozoic]] and Post-Palaeozoic Rocks of Wales''. Owen’s almost cartoon-like geological sketches became his hallmark, and illustrated his profound desire for people of all backgrounds and abilities to appreciate the magnificent geology of his native land.
Owen chaired the [[South Wales Geologists' Association|South Wales Group of the Geologists’ Association]], and an annual T.R. Owen memorial lecture has been instituted in his memory.
